This forecast is based off of three factors. First, because Amazon has been searching for its second headquarters for more than a year, it is logical to conclude that Amazon will hold a press conference to announce this decision. The concluding time for this challenge question is 2:59 AM EST on 1 October 2018, approximately two hours from now. Therefore, it is unlikely that Amazon will have a press conference to announce their decision, while their audience would be substantially suboptimal, within the next two hours.﻿ Second, reports have been published that Amazon officials visited a Chicago bid location in late August, alluding to the fact that the selection process is ongoing (https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-hq2-reps-visited-chicago-second-time-report-2018-9). These officials' trip to the Chicago location is notable, as " it could mean the contest is far from over, and it may be more-open than had previously been speculated." (https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-hq2-reps-visited-chicago-second-time-report-2018-9). Lastly,  Amazon officials have asserted that they will make their decision by the end of the year and strategically it would be the most logical to wait to select a city until after the 2018 elections, as Amazon will seek to ensure that the deals and incentives that they received from respective city and state governments are still valid post-election (https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-to-announce-the-location-of-its-second-hq-by-the-end-of-2018-2018-9)

https://www.salon.com/2018/09/17/it-looks-like-amazon-is-leaning-towards-washington-dc-for-hq2-based-on-a-ton-of-clues_partner/ "Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is set to headline a meeting on Thursday of The Economic Club of Washington DC, a city that just so happens to be increasingly talked about as the probable choice for Amazon’s HQ2, based on a ton of clues that keep piling up. Speculation about where the e-commerce giant will decide to put down stakes for its second US headquarters has ramped up considerably in recent days, with the announcement of the winning location seemingly pretty imminent. Conventional wisdom is that the announcement is coming anytime now, certainly by the end of the year, and we’re already passed the one-year mark since the search got under way. Bezos reportedly won’t have an announcement to make on Thursday, according to a Tuesday afternoon report from The Washington Post. Intriguingly, though, Amazon’s board of directors will be in town, too, leading to speculation that Jeff wants to show off the city to them ahead of a formal announcement. It’s not yet clear if there will be a formal meeting of the board while in DC. Meanwhile, among some of the other clues making DC seem likely a likely choice: Amazon has just joined the Washington DC Chamber of Commerce as a paying member.. . .  At the end of July, the Puget Sound Business Journal also spotted an Amazon job listing that sought a DC-based economic development manager — a job the company doesn’t appear to have posted in any other city, according to the paper. “The job posting says Amazon is looking for someone with experience in economic incentives, which will likely play a major factor in its HQ2 project. It says the economic development manager would work directly with ‘state and community’ officials, but makes no mention of the federal government, the focus of much of Amazon’s existing D.C. workforce.” Bezos (who, let’s not forget, personally owns The Washington Post) apparently already owns the largest home in DC, or will soon. The Post itself reported back in 2017 that Bezos had bought two mansions there, one of which he intended to turn into the largest in the city.  Business Insider has reported that of the 20 remaining HQ2 contenders believed to still be on Amazon’s short list, three of those are in the DC metro area. Fun fact: Washington DC is the only metro area with that many contenders left on the short list. Also per BI, “Northern Virginia is attractive for tech firms due to its proximity to Data Center Alley, where 70% of the United States’ internet traffic flows through. That means more efficiency and reliability, as well as cheaper power.” People are starting to be so convinced DC is going to be the winning locale that we’re already starting to see thinkpieces about whether or not Amazon will be good for the area. (See the Washingtonian’s “Would Amazon’s HQ2 Really Be Good for Washington?”) One way or another, it looks like we won’t have to wait much longer to find out.

So far, Amazon staff have visited about half, with more trips scheduled for April and beyond. The company plans to make a decision by Dec. 31, barring some huge upset, and once it's made, hiring in the anointed town will begin in 2019. Austin and Dallas got their Amazon visits at the beginning of March. Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he believes either city would be a "perfect fit" for Amazon, touting his state's excellent workforce, low cost of living, reasonable regulation, low tax rate and ease of doing business.  Chicago hosted the Amazon team for two days the week of March 19. One blip in the process was a pre-tour graffiti clean-up blitz that mistakenly destroyed a piece of wall art by French street artist Blek le Rat on a building in the Logan Square area. It’s across from Lincoln Yards, a 70-acre riverfront site that’s one of Chicago’s prime contenders for the Amazon placement.  Chicago was not above playing hardball. It hired actor William Shatner, aka Capt. Kirk, to narrate a video suggesting America's Second City for Amazon's Second Headquarters. Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos is a serious Star Trek fan, so much so that he had a bit part in the movie Star Trek Beyond. Denver had a 10-person group tour the city the last week of January. Little has been revealed about the visit beyond word that the Amazon team took a ride on the light-rail train from the Denver airport into town, according to the Denver Post.  New York City and Newark are rumored to be gearing up for an Amazon foray in April, according to Bisnow, a local business news site. The Star-Ledger reported the trip was originally slated for the first week of March but weather — in fact, a blizzard — caused it to be rescheduled.  Both New York City and Newark, which are just 12 miles apart, are considered to be on the short list of finalists.   Philadelphia got a visit, but it's not exactly clear when Amazon came. Mayor Jim Kenney told the Philadelphia Inquirer only that the Seattle team came for about a day and a half, but wouldn't say when or what they did, beyond that they didn't meet directly with him. The Washington, D.C., area has three separate areas vying for the Amazon headquarters: Washington, D.C., itself, Montgomery County, Md., and Northern Virginia. All three got visits the first week of March. Both Virginia and Maryland are offering up cities near to D.C. Virginia suggests Alexandria and Arlington, while Maryland has focused on the White Flint area of North Bethesda, which is near a Metro station with a direct link to Washington, D.C. Washington, D.C., has been seen as a front-runner in the fight to get Amazon, for several reasons. One is its proximity to the federal government, which would give the Seattle company more of a hometown advantage as it fends off suggestions that the rapidly growing enterprise be tamed by regulation or taxation.  Another is simply that CEO Jeff Bezos already has a house there — though it’s hardly just a house. The $23 million, 27,000-square-foot mansion used to be a museum and is the largest private home in the District of Columbia. It is within blocks of the homes of both Barack and Michelle Obama and Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump. The historic neighborhood, Kalorama, has long been home to diplomats and the power elite. As yet, there's no word of when other contenders, including Boston; Columbus, Ohio; Indianapolis; Los Angeles; Miami; Nashville; Pittsburgh; Raleigh, N.C.; and Toronto, will get their visits.

The trouble with this question is the difficulty in establishing a base rate. Nonetheless,
floundering around as I am, let’s start by asking whether or not the decision will be made by 1st October 2018? The proposal says the decision will be made in 2018 but I doubt Amazon are bound by that. If a few final contenders are being played off against each other it could take longer. On the other hand Amazon does appear to be struggling for space in Seattle, even renting office space above a shop, and so clearly has a powerful incentive to get a move on. Neither does it appear that Amazon is simply holding a gun to Seattle’s head because 1) the anti-business vibe in the city means such tactics are unlikely to work, and 2) they intend to leave the original HQ there. I’m prepared to take them at their word on this one, and making the assumption that the announcement could be any day in 2018 with equal likelihood. That gives us a 75% chance that the decision will be before 1st October and the “No” answer a 25%. As to which particular city they’re going to end up in I’m relying on the work linked in the question by Mark Zandi and Adam Ozimek of economy.com. I’ll jump to the conclusion that the choice will come from the top 10 cities they identify and weigh the top pick (Austin) having a 15% chance, the second (Atlanta)  with 14% and so on. Making a pro rata adjustment for the 25% chance that the decision is not made by 1st October gives the results presented.

Amazon has stated they are looking for metro areas over 1 million in population with business friendly environments and the ability to attract and retain strong talent. Austin, TX and Dallas, TX are strong contenders in this case due to their growing populations and proximity to the University of Texas and Texas A&M which turn out a large number of graduates in engineering and technology disciplines. Additionally, Texas typically offers significant tax incentives, and has land costs which are much lower than alternatives in the Northeast, such as New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, or Washington D.C. With Amazon planning to employ upwards of 50,000 people, this is likely a major factor in the decision making process.  The Northeast does have the benefit of large numbers of college graduates with the required skills, but the cost of living is higher in that region, so starting salaries would need to be higher as well. Amazon would also be competing with many other tech companies for talent in the Boston, New York, DC corridor.

To explain my thought process: - I tried to not be too much influenced by Moody's model. I'm not confident it reflects Amazon true strategic challenges. 
- My first thought was: their main challenge for the new HQ: attracting and retaining the right talents, especially in Computer Science, Robotics and Machine Learning/AI (San Francisco, NYC/Boston) -- I put aside the people in sales (especially a need for their B2B marketplace), ops, finance, etc. where the shortage isn't as big as the three specialities mentioned 
- Checking at their job webpage, I verified that their main shortage are people in Computer Science (2258 positions opened), so they'll need a city attractive for developers (ie: good tech ecosystem & universities) - https://www.amazon.jobs/fr/search?base_query=&loc_query=%25C3%2589tats-Unis&country=USA
- The most attractive hubs for people working in tech are (Seattle excluded): 
> for robotic: San Francisco, San Jose, Boston, Washington DC, Pittsburgh - all in Eastern, Atlantic, or Newfoundland Time Zones - https://www.quora.com/Which-geographical-area-in-the-US-is-the-hub-of-robotics-jobs-internships
> for ML/AI: California (San Francisco / Palo Alto / Cambridge), NYC/Boston & to a lesser extent Montreal - all in Eastern, Atlantic, or Newfoundland Time Zones 
> for CS : California (SF, Palo Alto, San Jose...), NYC/Boston, Seatle (all EAN TimeZones) and to a lesser extent Austin (Central), Raley (Eastern) & Madison (Central) // (https://techbeacon.com/10-best-cities-for-software-engineers ; http://www.businessinsider.fr/us/25-best-cities-to-be-programmer-2016-7/#no-9-portland-oregon-89374-17). I'd add Montreal/Toronto here as well but they are all in Eastern Time Zones so it wouldn't influence the choice. 
- If it would be another tech giants, I would at that point be much more betting on Eastern, Atlantic or Newfoundland Time Zones. Yet, Jeff Bezos has built a culture around customer satisfaction at the lowest cost possible. And there is always the tradeoff between quality of human capital and cost (tax incentive, affordability of life - thus wages). 
- Checking back the articles & seeing that they plan to hire 50k people, it cannot be only for top talents in robotics and AI (they can do it in San Francisco, Palo Alto, Sunnyvale & Cambridge where already are) 
- If I were looking for more affordable cities than the big tech hubs (checked moody's model for that) with very high human capital (in tech), my top 3 would be: Pittsburgh (Amazon already there - eastern), Raley (Eastern) & Austin (Central). 
- So I would overall bet on Easter (for California, NY/Boston, etc.) but keep a good probability on Austin, especially because it attracted other tech champions (Samsung & Apple, has a very influential tech event (SXSW) and a strong tech ecosystem, at a cost affordable and many other reasons --http://www.businessinsider.fr/us/amazon-hq2-could-be-austin-why-2017-10/) -- this sounds like a very Amazon-like choice. Yet it is one city against many other very good choices. - When I made a new check (through this article especially - https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/09/09/upshot/where-should-amazon-new-headquarters-be.html), I realized I had missed Denver & Boulder (Moutain Standard Time) even if they are not as much attractive compared to the other cities to date. I've increased a bit the probability of it. I didn't mention that much Pittsburgh either but it is in the Eastern Time Zone so it has not much influence on the probability. I feel my biggest risk is to have overstated the assumption that their main shortage were CS people, missed some other key competencies or other factors that they weight more than I would - focusing on people. Questions about the game in itself: I've seen that the score was Brier's which would encourage us to make sure the probabilities reflect our beliefs. But then I've seen that they make the difference between the average Brier's and ours. Isn't that incentivizing us to be a bit more radical than what we'd be otherwise? (reflecting the average prediction would only lead to 0 point isn't it?

I predict it is most likely Amazon will establish its new HQ (AHQ2) in one of the cities of the EST, AST, NFST time zones (55%). Next highest probability is allocated to CST time zone (23%), then PST/AlST/HAST time zone (12%), and lastly out of the US time zones MST time zone (8%). I predict there to be a equal minimal chance of 1% that Amazon will either locate its new HQ in another time zone or will not announce the new location before 1st of October 2018. My prediction is based on the following. Base rates: •	I used the Moody’s model and data set that included the geographic variable to establish my first base rate. The data set can be downloaded from Moody’s site.
o	Moody’s considered 65 cities as a possible location for AHQ2 – all other things equal there would be a 1/65 chance of any of these cities being nominated which averages to ≈ 1,54% per city. 
o	Moody’s had also used numerous variables to calculate the most likely/suitable city for the AHQ2. I used these scores to calculate what percentage would equal to one score point of Moody’s model. This came to ≈ 0,59% per point. Using this I calculated the percentage scores of all the cities, divided the cities according to their time zones and added up the cities percentage points in the time zones.
https://www.economy.com/dismal/analysis/commentary/298321/Where-Amazons-Next-Headquarters-Should-Go/  •	As my second base rate I used New York Time’s article in which they also calculate the most likely city to receive the AHQ2 nomination. Here I devised my own scoring system in which every city got 1 point for meeting any of five NYT criteria (as a start each city on the list got 1 point for making it to the list) + added my own geography criteria (my assumption that Amazon would locate AHQ2 some distance away from the current Seattle HQ). In the geography variable all cities not in the PST time zone were given a 1 point while PST zone cities each received a 0. Per point percentage came to ≈ 0,67%. I then carried out same calculations as with the first data set.
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/09/09/upshot/where-should-amazon-new-headquarters-be.html •	Lastly I averaged the two base rates. Key Facts:
•	Amazon has stated it will announce the location of its new HQ in 2018.
o	The likelihood of „NO“ thus minimal (1%). Key Assumptions:
•	I assume Amazon wants the other HQ to be located some distance from the Seattle HQ.
o	Geography factored into both base rates.
•	Amazon is not going to announce its HQ2 abroad – I assume it would be too much of a negative reaction especially with Trump’s administration emphasizing bring jobs back to US.
o	Minimal probability that AHQ2 would be located anywhere outside US thus outside the given US time zones.
o	In worst case I assume AHQ2 will be located either in Canada or Mexico – both still in North American time zones.  Key Indicators:
•	Prior to announcing a winner, Amazon will announce time zone/region where it intends to locate its new HQ; announce a TOP 10/20/30 list of the locations it is considering locating its new HQ. Links:
